fr:mainmatter.html:p: Each semester as part of Lei's group, I am obligated to present a paper / sequence of papers to the group. Here are the slides for these presentations.

I am a PhD student at the University of Michigan as part of the Electrical and Computer Engineering program, where I work on reinforcement learning. My PhD advisor is Lei Ying. Previously, I obtained a BS from the University of Michigan in Mathematics and Computer Science, where I graduated with honors and high honors respectively. During my undergrad, I worked with Lei Ying as part of the SURE Program and as a teaching assitant for EECS 602. My full CV is also available here.

This is my forest (shoutout to Jon Sterling who is remarkably helpful). This website functions both as a personal knowledge management system, where I store my notes in notebooks and also have some additional external resources in /dev/null. Additionally, I store my thoughts in a variety of consumption mediums. Namely, short-form notes / blog posts can be found in the "marginalia". I also maintain two weekly posting obligations: a weeknotes / lifelog and a paper of the week.

html:ul.html:li: [September. 2024] I will officially be starting my PhD at University of Michigan
[August. 2024] I finished my undergraduate thesis and officially graduated!
[May. 2024] Our paper got accepted by Reinforcement Learning Conference

fr:title.text: Meta Learning for Continual Reinforcement Learning: An Investigation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Meta Learning for Continual Reinforcement Learning: An Investigation
Cost Aware Best Arm Identification
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @misc{kanariosCostAwareBest2024, title = {Cost {{Aware Best Arm Identification}}}, author = {Kanarios, Kellen and Zhang, Qining and Ying, Lei}, year = {2024}, doi = {10.48550/arXiv.2402.16710}, urldate = {2025-06-27}, number = {arXiv:2402.16710}, publisher = {arXiv}, file = {/home/kellen/Downloads/pdfs/storage/KCBBU7NQ/Kanarios et al. - 2024 - Cost Aware Best Arm Identification.pdf}, keywords = {Computer Science - Machine Learning,Statistics - Machine Learning}, langid = {english}, archiveprefix = {arXiv}, abstract = {In this paper, we study a best arm identification problem with dual objects. In addition to the classic reward, each arm is associated with a cost distribution and the goal is to identify the largest reward arm using the minimum expected cost. We call it Cost Aware Best Arm Identification (CABAI), which captures the separation of testing and implementation phases in product development pipelines and models the objective shift between phases, i.e., cost for testing and reward for implementation. We first derive a theoretical lower bound for CABAI and propose an algorithm called CTAS to match it asymptotically. To reduce the computation of CTAS, we further propose a simple algorithm called Chernoff Overlap (CO), based on a square-root rule, which we prove is optimal in simplified two-armed models and generalizes well in numerical experiments. Our results show that (i) ignoring the heterogeneous action cost results in sub-optimality in practice, and (ii) simple algorithms can deliver near-optimal performance over a wide range of problems.}, primaryclass = {cs}, eprint = {2402.16710}, month = {July} }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This is my blog, in which I write about a variety of topics including computer science, mathematics, and more. For more short-form blogs, see the marginalia. See upcoming blogs and feel free to request! This blog also has a corresponding Atom feed (if on chrome you need a feed reader).

I have been using LazyVim for some time now, but I have now run into issues multiple times where understanding how LazyVim is doing something is far more difficult than if I had written my own setup. I allocated one day for this adventure and really just wanted to make sure I had support for \TeX , python, forester, and C/C++. Due to my (self-imposed) time constraint, I do not have the associated resources linked for each of the things discussed below. At some point, I hope to come back and more thoroughly cover each of the components.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: To my surprise, a lot of the features that I had come to take for granted were actually options set up internally by Lazyvim. For example, I was shocked with 8 space indents!! and I could not even copy from one terminal instance to another... Due to this, I went and found all of the options I liked from Lazyvim and added them to my new configuration in configs/options.lua.
For this, we will be using the defacto standard lazy.nvim. This is actually straightforward and kind of "just works". Just follow the installation guide in their documentation.

This is one of the main motivations for me making the switch. It seems nvim-cmp has finally been replaced with a new blink.cmp, so that is what we will be using.
Kellen Kanarios202534Rebuilding My (Neo)Vim Config From Scratch › Language Server Protocol It turns out there is a lot that goes into getting LSP setup correctly.
First we must actually install the language servers. To do this the easiest way, we use the mason.nvim and mason.nvim-lspconfig plugins. At some point, I might actually figure out how to set up lsp myself without lspconfig but that point is not now.
Through nvim-lspconfig, we can set up each of the servers we want to have LSP support. I just set up clangd, pyright, and texlab. This was a bit ridiculous. The first of many challenges was around import resolution in python. To remedy this, I needed to write a function to find the virtual environment directory and then set the pythonPath to the venv python binary. Previously, I think I was just using pylsp and installing it as a pip package to each python venv. I much prefer the new way, and I think pyright is overall a much better lsp.
Kellen Kanarios202534Rebuilding My (Neo)Vim Config From Scratch › Forester Completion Another necessary completion source for me is the one provided by forester.nvim. Similar to vimtex, the reference completion support is VERY useful. Obviously, I need completion when I am writing this blog!!! This was a little more involved. The first difficulty was that the completion source provided by the forester.nvim plugin was for nvim-cmp. It turns out this is a prevalent enough problem that the author of blink.cmp wrote an additional plugin blink.compat to allow for nvim-cmp completion sources. While this sounds all fine and good, nvim-compat expects plugins that return the completion source themselves, whereas in forester.nvim the completion source is just one submodule of a more feature-rich plugin. To get around this, I needed to look into the blink.compat code and find how they are registering the sources and just do it myself.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Going all the way back to the Gilles Castel blog post, I have always been partial to snippets that auto-expand. I had them set up prior to Lazyvim but with Lazyvim I had resigned to using friendly-snippets with native nvim snippets. Since I was already redoing everything, this time around I decided not to compromise. Once upon a time (right when it came out I think?) I tried out Luasnips, but it seems that they now have far more extensive features. They are also natively supported by blink.cmp!! It feels necessary that I plug the awesome repo that ports the original Ultisnips snippets to Luasnip. With this, I was able to easily add my own forester snippets!!!

A fun little thing that I had been hoping to do for awhile and is finally now possible - I can load latex snippets when inside math environments in forester!!!! To do this, I looked into the forester treesitter grammar and found the corresponding nodetypes for math envs. It was then straightforward to detect whether we were in a math env and to load the associated latex snippets.

There is a very cool add-on to anki called AnkiConnect that has an associated plugin anki.nvim. Basically, AnkiConnects allows you to make requests to Anki and receive/send useful information from/to your decks. Unfortunately, anki.nvim built-in commands didn't seem all that useful to me. However, it provided the necessary infrastructure for me to accomplish my desired workflow.

Namely, I made my own command that queries Anki for the deck names, which you can then pick from using telescope pickers. When you select one it will create a new flashcard in a specified flashcard directory under a directory created based on the deck name. You can then send this card to that deck using the existing AnkiSend command.

I also continued the snippet fun here. When writing Anki cards, you can write latex code between [latex] [/latex] delimiters. I wrote a quick function to detect whether we are in these delimiters and if we are then to load the latex snippets from the previous section. I also added some basic anki filetype plugins to insert things like these delimiters.

I am currently interested in continual reinforcement learning or more specifically how to learn generalizable representations online. With this, I am currently looking into contrastive / zero-shot / hierarchical RL. If these things sound interesting I would love to talk about your research and potential collaboration opportunities. Schedule a meeting!
If you are a student at University of Michigan, I also have opinions / advice on courses. Additionally, I am advising a few undergraduates with my advisor.
